title: 107_s2971
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002" and pertains to Indian Reservation Roads. The Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002 amends the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century by authorizing appropriations for fiscal years 1998 to 2009 and adjusting the obligation ceiling. The Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002 further amends the Transportation Equity Act for the 21st Century by increasing the obligation authority for Indian reservation road bridges and roads under title 23, United States Code. Additionally, it provides additional contract authority for states with Indian reservations for fiscal years 2004 to 2009. The Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002 increases funding for Indian reservation road bridges and roads under title 23, United States Code. $15,000,000 is authorized annually from the Highway Trust Fund for planning, design, construction, and inspection of projects to replace bridges. The Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002 authorizes $15,000,000 annually for projects to replace bridges on Indian reservation roads. Funds allocated for these projects can be obligated in the same manner as apportioned funds under chapter 1. Approval by the Secretary of plans, specifications, and estimates is required for these projects. The Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002 authorizes $15,000,000 annually for bridge replacement projects on Indian reservation roads. Funds are distributed based on the actual need of each reservation, determined by the number of deficient bridges and projected rehabilitation costs. The distribution of funds to Indian tribes must be fair, equitable, and based on valid transportation needs. The Tribal Transportation Program Improvement Act of 2002 authorizes $15,000,000 annually for bridge replacement projects on Indian reservation roads. Funds are distributed based on the actual need of each reservation, determined by the number of deficient bridges and projected rehabilitation costs. Section 204(j) of title 23, United States Code, is amended to increase the distribution percentage from 2% to 4% for Indian Reservation Roads Planning. SEC. 3. INDIAN RESERVATION RURAL TRANSIT PROGRAM. The Indian Reservation Rural Transit Program under Section 5311 of title 49, United States Code, allows the Secretary of Transportation to provide competitive grants to Indian tribes for establishing rural transit programs on reservations or tribal lands. Grants are based on the tribes' needs. The Secretary of Transportation determines the funding based on the Indian tribe's needs, allocating $20,000,000 annually for the program under section 5338. The Sense of Congress regarding Indian Reservation Roads is outlined in Section 4. Congress finds that the Bureau of Indian Affairs is responsible for maintaining roads on Indian reservations, but current funding only covers 30% of the needed amount. It is crucial to provide sufficient funding for road maintenance to prevent waste on construction projects.
